meta.title: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information - Hunterdon Central Regional High School

meta.name: description
meta.content: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information - Hunterdon Central Regional High School

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information, Hunterdon Central Regional High School
Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information - Hunterdon Central Regional High School
Coronavirus (Covid-19) Information - Hunterdon Central Regional High School

body.class: fsLiveMode fsHasHeader fsHasLeftBanner fsHasMenu fsHasFooter fsHasOneColumnLayout fsSection123 fsHasTheme2

li.a: Option II: A Guide for Students & Parents

div.p: At the directive of the Office of the Governor, Hunterdon Central was closed effective Monday, March 16, 2020. Online home instruction for all students began on Tuesday, March 17, 2020. All extracurricular events and activities were canceled, effective Saturday, March 14, 2020.

Governor Murphy has announced that schools in New Jersey will remain closed and engaged in online remote instruction through at least May 15, 2020, when he will reassess if a longer closure is necessry.
Detailed information on online/virtual instruction can be found on this webpage: Information on Home Instruction

section.div:
While television news and social media are providing non-stop coverage and rumors about the virus, much of the information presented is unsubstantiated. We strongly recommend using the following expert sources for facts and updates. They provide the best information on prevention strategies, how to protect yourself, and what to do if you think you are sick. :
Centers for Disease Control & Prevention
New Jersey Department of Health Communicable Disease Service
Hunterdon County Department of Health
Information on Essential Childcare from the New Jersey Department of Education Hunterdon healthcare is offering a hotline on coronavirus: 908-788-6440. The hotline will be open seven days a week,from 8:00 AM - 8:00 PM.

header.h2: Resources for Dealing with Coronavirus & Social Distancing:

div.p: This pandemic represents a significant disruption to all of our lives. Children, in particular, may struggle with this disruption, and may have difficulty talking about it. The Centers for Disease Control offers advice on how to talk to children about the virus and the disruptions that it is causing:

strong.span: Messages for parents, school staff, and others working with children.

div.p: The following resources offer information on how to deal with anxiety and stress created by the virus and the isolation caused by social distancing:

strong.span: Centers for Disease Control: Manage Anxiety & Stress

span.a: Anxiety & Depression Association of America: Coronavirus Anxiety - Expert Tips & Resources

section.div:
Hunterdon Central been working with the Hunterdon County Office of Emergency Management and Hunterdon Medical Center to help address shortages in supplies, particularly personal protective equipment. The District has donated 1,600 surgical masks and 45 boxes of gloves to Hunterdon Medical Center. If you are looking for a way to help, please visit these sites:
Hunterdon County Office of Emergency Management
Hunterdon Healthcare

header.h2: Frequently Asked Questions on Closure & Online Instruction

li.a: Is campus closed to all uses, including extracurricular activities and community use?
How long will this closure last?
How will students continue their studies?
Is there a schedule for online instruction?
What if a student's District Chromebook is broken or not working?
What if a student does not have internet access at home?
Will students receive grades for work during the closure?
Are meals available during the closure?
If a student needs help from a Counselor or a Student Assistance Counselor, how can they be reached?
How can Vice Principals, House Office staff, or other staff members be contacted?
What will happen to AP, NJSLA, and other standardized testing?

h2.a: Is campus closed to all uses, including extracurricular activities and community use?

div.p: Hunterdon Central's campus is closed to students and to the public for all uses, except for scheduled pickups and deliveries. All events, activities, and athletics are canceled until further notice. District facilities such as the track are also closed to community use. The NJSIAA Website posts the latest information on the status of spring athletics.

h2.a: How long will this closure last?

div.div: Governor Murphy's orders for school closure and social distancing do not have an end date. The high school will remain closed until we receive further instructions from the Governor's Office .

h2.a: How will students continue their studies?

div.p: Students will engage in online/virtual work with their teachers. We are utilizing student Chromebooks and various online tools (including Google Classroom and Google Sites) to conduct this work. Students have choice and variety in the assignments. Teachers will also adhere to required modifications and accommodations in any student’s 504 Plan or Special Education Individualized Education Plan (IEP). Parents of special education students can contact their case manager with any questions or concerns. Case managers will be reaching out to parents regarding any scheduled IEP meetings. You can read specific information about online instruction here: Information about Home Instruction.

h2.a: Is there a schedule for online instruction?

div.p: Students are generally free to schedule their work in the way that works best for them. We recommend that students follow our delayed opening schedule as they plan their work.

img.br: This is not a requirement, but may help students pace their work. Note that teachers will be available during those hours via email and through tools that they communicated to their students (i.e., Google Classroom, etc.) Teachers may also schedule events, videos, online lectures, and other activities at specific times during the closure.

div.p: You can view additional details about virtual instruction here: Information on Home Instruction

h2.a: What if a student's District Chromebook is broken or not working?

div.p: If there is an issue with a District-issued Chromebook, please contact our Help Desk: helpdesk@hcrhs.org
You may also use a home computer (or even a tablet, such as an iPad) to access online instruction activities and materials, using your District Google account.

h2.a: What if a student does not have internet access at home?

div.p: Please contact our Help Desk at helpdesk@hcrhs.org to explore options for internet access or to make other arrangements. Comcast is offering their Internet Essentials Program free of charge for two months to qualifying families.

h2.a: Will students receive grades for work during the closure?

div.p: Students are required to complete their assignments and should be working on them every school day. For now, student participation and communication with their teachers about work will establish attendance. If a student is not submitting work, or is otherwise out of touch with a teacher, that teacher may submit the student’s name as a potential absence. We will reach out to parents of any student who is potentially absent. If the closure continues deeper into the spring, we will share more information about grading of work completed during the closure.

h2.a: Are meals available during the closure?

div.p: Students who are eligible for free or reduced meals at Hunterdon Central can pick up breakfast and lunch. Please contact Gymlyn Corbin at gcorbin@hcrhs.org or call 908-284-7110 for information and instructions.

h2.a: If a student needs help from a Counselor or a Student Assistance Counselor, how can they be reached?

div.p: Counselors will be in touch with each of their students via email. Some counselors are using Google Sites and Google Classroom to share resources. Counselors are also monitoring voicemail. All counselors will be via email or other online tools during the hours the hours of the schedule posted under the tab "Is there a schedule for online instruction?"

h2.a: How can Vice Principals, House Office staff, or other staff members be contacted?

div.p: Hunterdon Central staff are all available via email and are monitoring phone voicemail during the closure. Contact information can be found on our website : Hunterdon Central Contact Information.
If you have any trouble finding a contact, or have more general questions, please contact Nancy Tucker at ntucker@hcrhs.org.

h2.a: What will happen to AP, NJSLA, and other standardized testing?

div.div: The College Board has begun to announce changes to this year's AP testing procedures. Please see their latest announcement here. While there are many questions still unanswered, we are working with teachers of AP classes to prepare for this year's testing.

The US Department of Education has announced flexibility on annual required testing in mathematics, language arts, and science. Formerly known as PARCC, these are now known collectively as New Jersey Student Learning Assessment, or NJSLA. The New Jersey Department of Education has announced that NJSLA assessments are canceled for Spring 2020.

div.p:
Hunterdon Central Regional High School
84 Route 31, Flemington, NJ, 08822
(908)782-5727
